ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.TITLE: Accessible Programming
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.INTRO_P1: Programming with Micro:bit offers an excellent opportunity to introduce people of all ages and abilities to the world of technology. However, to ensure it is truly inclusive, it is essential to consider accessibility from the project design stage.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.INTRO_P2: Accessibility cannot be a patch that is added at the end of the project to try to meet a requirement or obtain benefits.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.CREATION_P1: To create accessible Micro:bit projects, it is important to consider several aspects:
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.CREATION_LI1_TEXT: Use not only the LED screen, but also sound (if the Micro:bit model allows it or is connected to a speaker) to provide information. For example, a game can emit one sound when you get it right and a different one when you get it wrong.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.CREATION_LI2_TEXT: Consider options beyond buttons A and B. The Micro:bit's pins can be connected to external sensors or adapted switches, facilitating interaction for people with reduced mobility. Another option is to use the Micro:bit's accelerometer.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.CREATION_LI3_TEXT: Keep the programs as simple and clear as possible. Avoid complex action sequences that may confuse users with cognitive or memory difficulties.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.CREATION_LI4_TEXT: Provide detailed and easy-to-understand instructions, ideally in multiple formats (text, audio, pictograms).
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.BLOCKLY_P1: Block-based programming interfaces, like the one used by MakeCode for Micro:bit, are a powerful tool for accessibility. Their visual and intuitive nature reduces significant barriers:
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.BLOCKLY_OVERCOME_LI1_TEXT: Although visual interfaces can be a challenge, the use of color-coded blocks allows users with low vision to recognize the type of block being used more quickly and easily.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.BLOCKLY_OVERCOME_LI2_TEXT: Manipulating blocks is often easier than typing code, especially with mouse or keyboard adaptations. The drag-and-drop function can be replaced by keyboard navigation for those who cannot use a mouse.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.BLOCKLY_OVERCOME_LI3_TEXT: The visual representation of the code reduces the cognitive load, as it does not require memorizing complex syntax. The blocks guide the user through the logical structure of the program.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.BLOCKLY_CHALLENGES_LI1_TEXT: Often, drag-and-drop interfaces are not fully compatible with screen readers, which makes interaction difficult for blind or severely low-vision individuals.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.BLOCKLY_CHALLENGES_LI2_TEXT: Full and efficient keyboard-only navigation is not always perfectly implemented in all block-based programming platforms.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.BLOCKLY_CHALLENGES_LI3_TEXT: The lack of customization options (font size, color contrast, removal of animations) can affect users with various visual or cognitive needs.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.BLOCKLY_CHALLENGES_LI4_TEXT: Documentation and examples of projects specifically designed with accessibility in mind are not always available.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.PYTHON_P1: As an alternative to block-based programming, code-based programming (microPython or JavaScript) can be used. This type of programming, being plain text, is highly accessible to screen readers.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.PYTHON_P2: The problem with this type of programming is that users must have a minimum knowledge of the programming language, so they have to be taught the language and the concepts at the same time. This does not happen with block-based programming, as knowledge of the language is not necessary and the main concepts worked on are programming concepts such as variables, constants, loops, etc.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.PYTHON_P3: The only procedure currently available to minimize this barrier (language knowledge) is the creation of programming blocks where the student only has to replace or complete part of the code. The creation of the skeleton of the programming blocks in code would be the only current option to ensure 100% access via a screen reader.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.PYTHON_P4: Promoting accessible programming not only benefits people with disabilities, but also improves the experience for all users, promoting a culture of inclusive design in the field of technology.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.PYTHON_P5: Below are two examples, one example where the Micro:bit's response is only done through the display and another, more accessible, where the information output is done through the display and is reinforced with a sound output.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.MODAL_NON_ACCESSIBLE_P: The video clip of the non-accessible example would go here.
ACCESSIBLE_PROGRAMMING.MODAL_ACCESSIBLE_P: The video clip of the accessible example would go here.

SETTINGS.TITLE: Settings
SETTINGS.DESCRIPTION: Here you can adjust the application settings.

MICROPYTHON_PAGE.H1: MicroPython Programming Course for Micro:bit (Emphasis on Accessibility)
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.P_INTRO: This course will introduce you to the exciting world of programming with MicroPython on the Micro:bit board. You will learn to create interactive projects, with a special focus on how to make them accessible to all users, regardless of their abilities. The Micro:bit is a small programmable computer designed to make learning to code fun and accessible. With MicroPython, an optimized dialect of Python for microcontrollers, you can write code simply and efficiently.
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.H2_MODULE1: Module 1: First Steps and Accessible Outputs
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.P_MODULE1_BASIC: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.H3_MODULE1_LED: Displaying Text on the LED Screen (with Accessibility Considerations)
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.P_MODULE1_LED: We will learn to use the Micro:bit's LED matrix to display messages. It is crucial to consider that visually impaired users may not perceive this output. Later, we will explore alternative methods for communicating information.
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.H2_MODULE2: Module 2: Interactive Inputs and Multisensory Feedback
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.P_MODULE2_INPUTS: We will explore how buttons A and B, as well as digital inputs, can be used to interact with our programs. For accessibility, we will consider how these inputs can be adapted or supplemented.
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.P_MODULE2_SOUND: Auditory feedback is essential for accessibility. We will learn to use the buzzer (or external speaker) to provide sounds that reinforce visual information or replace it completely for visually impaired users. For example, if a game requires the user to press a button, a combination of a visual arrow on the LED screen and a distinctive sound when the button is pressed can significantly improve the experience for everyone.
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.H2_MODULE3: Module 3: Sensors and Adaptations for Functional Diversity
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.P_MODULE3_SENSORS: The Micro:bit has several built-in sensors that allow us to interact with the environment. We will learn to read data from the accelerometer (to detect movement), the compass (for orientation), and the temperature sensor.
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.P_MODULE3_ADAPTATIONS: We will analyze how sensor data can be used to create alternative interactions. For example, a program that is activated by tilting the Micro:bit could be more accessible for people with reduced mobility than a traditional button. In addition, we will see how the information obtained from the sensors can be translated into multisensory outputs (visual, auditory, tactile).
MICROPYTHON_PAGE.P_CONCLUSIONS: This course has covered the basics of MicroPython programming with a strong emphasis on accessible design. Remember that accessibility is not an additional feature, but a fundamental principle for creating technology inclusive. We encourage you to explore more projects and continue learning how to make technology accessible to everyone!

ACCESSIBILITY_EVALUATOR_PAGE.H2: MicroPython Code Editor with Accessibility Emphasis
ACCESSIBILITY_EVALUATOR_PAGE.P: Enter your MicroPython code for Micro:bit in the text area. The editor will help you visualize what the code looks like and allow you to check its accessibility.

AUDIO_FEEDBACK.ERROR_SUGGESTION: Add 'speech.say("[string]")', 'music.play(music.[song])' or 'music.([number])' for visually impaired users to receive information.
AUDIO_FEEDBACK.ERROR_SUGGESTION_2: Import 'speech' or 'music' for visually impaired users to receive information.
AUDIO_FEEDBACK.MISSING_AUDIO_OUTPUT_WITH_DISPLAY_SHOW: You are only using display.show() without audio output.
AUDIO_FEEDBACK.SUGGEST_AUDIO_OUTPUT_WITH_DISPLAY_SHOW: Add 'import speech' or 'import music' and use 'speech.say()' or 'music.play()' to provide auditory feedback for visually impaired users.

BLOCKING_LOOPS.WARNING_SUGGESTION: You are using very long sleep(). This prevents the Micro:bit from reacting quickly to buttons or voice commands.

INPUT_REDUNDANCY.SUCCESS_MESSAGE: Accessible input: You use touch or motion sensors.
INPUT_REDUNDANCY.ERROR_SUGGESTION: Add 'pin_logo.is_touched()' to make it easier for people with motor difficulties to use.

COMPLEX_PRESSES.WARNING_SUGGESTION: Avoid requesting the simultaneous pressing of two buttons or a button and the logo, as this makes interaction difficult for users with certain motor disabilities.
COMPLEX_PRESSES.SUCCESS_MESSAGE: Simple presses: No complex presses were detected.

CODE_SEMANTICS.WARNING_SUGGESTION: Use names like 'alarm_status' instead of 'a' to make it easier for screen readers to read.
